content:
Re: Version identifier in URL

David J. Fiander (davidf@worf.mks.com)
Fri, 31 May 1996 08:10:48 -0400

  • Messages sorted by: [ date ][ thread ][ subject ][ author ]
  • Next message: David J. Fiander: "Re: Versions and configurations"
  • Previous message: David J. Fiander: "Re: Versions and configurations"
  • Maybe in reply to: Jim Whitehead: "Version identifier in URL"
  • Next in thread: Scot Malloy: "Re: Version identifier in URL" 
> However, it is not entirely clear to me what the tradeoffs are between
> using the URL parameter mechanism (e.g., ";version={version identifier}")
> versus using the URL query mechanism (e.g., "?version={version
> identifier}").  Can any members of the list shed some light on the intent
> of these two mechanisms?  This information is unavailable in either the
> HTTP specification or RFC 1738 (Uniform Resource Locators).

The advantage to using the URL parameter mechanism is that it
allows you to specify a query against and old version of the
page, of course :-)

More to the point, URL queries are very common already, and I'd
worry about specifying a standard name for a query that might
conflict with somebody's existing query scripts.

- David
